comments.commentBody: Yes, Ruth did it twice and Pujols is now in the club, but Reggie is the Dawg: three homers on three consecutive pitches from three separate pitchers. Oh, and it was the final game in the series.
Die hard Giants fan here, but Tony La Russa is a class act and props to his team this evening!!!

City will win 2-0, Man United lacks City's firepower/creativity and I'm still not sold on their young goalie.  It was "smoke and mirrors" for Man U last year and now the their time of living on their reputation is at an end.
Plots created by Dr W.

I made a baggage handler at the Antananarivo Madagascar airport very happy when I gave him my new Yankees cap in 2008. Like most outside of the USA, he probably was like that guy in the New Yorker cartoon who said that he is fan of New York Yankees caps, not the Yankees.

Here is an American perspective:

You bring to US shores many, many of the prejudices and class issues you say you are leaving behind.

Most darker Indians I have met are petrified of being associated with or 'lumped in' with African Americans.

You pay plenty of taxes in the US, but you really add very little value to our social fabric. It is extremely rare for Indians to give anything of themselves outside of their 'community.' Ever help out in a soup kitchen or contribute to inner-city tutoring or GED preparation? (Only if it's employer-sponsored, I bet.)

US and multi-national corporations love your discipline and obedience. Being newer to industrialization than the West, you buy the corporate 'mission statement' hook, line, and sinker. There are probably very few 'Occupy Wall Street' protesters from the sub-continent. (Yes, we realize that's because you have the 'right education' and are more employable, hence less anger with income disparity issues!)

You are shocked, appalled, and angry when your American-born children reflect and enact a Western temperament -- which almost always includes parental disobedience and moodiness -- during their teen years. What exactly did you think was going to happen when you emigrated? You made your children Americans! They will always question authority and think as individuals.

Many American women find it difficult to report to Indian men in US corporations: They are spoken to in a patronizing or dismissive way. And the inverse is even more troublesome: Indian men having difficulty reporting to American female executives. This has set the equality movement in the US workplace back about 25 years. Thanks.

And here's the secret that many Americans ponder on a regular basis:

'If all the corporations are outsourcing to India, why are so many Indians still moving here?' Oh yeah, it must be that education issue again.
Same as #5 and #8, I like Texas head coach but can't bring myself to support a texas team....hope the cards keep going.
OK. So Mr. Mungee who lived in India-USA-India wants to return back. A judgmental, incoherent, long-winded and rambling blog for that?
I have worked for global companies since 1998 and have been all over the globe. I have seen yankee caps everywhere! Afew years back I was in Berlin & they were everywhere!

So you are saying that once you were back in India, you could not control your anger at tiny issues, became rude at many instances and it is Indian's faults? If you cannot control your haughtiness then stop blaming Indians for that. Have a good time in US, you need US but India doesn't needs you.

Dear Author,
My sympathies are with you for, it was disappointing for you to return to India.
I am however appalled at the reasoning. I am not sure how many years did you spend in US before your first return in 2006 and also the kind of family background you had before you left for US the first time.
The life you expected in India in 2006, through the marketing of Mr Friedman might have confused your juvenile thinking. Your generalization and conclusions based on your personal experiences are not just offensive but racist. Your rant and language lacks the maturity expected when commenting about a community, nation or people in general.
NYT should take a serious note about the immature, offensive and racist rant of a disillusioned soul that is trying to reason for his juvenile actions.
NYT needs to apologize for publishing such a rant.

Hi Sumedh,

Interesting read!!! I registestered on this portal only to post this comment. A very different perspective to what an Indian (Not sure if you have got American citizenship) thinks of India (The country he left).
I cannot comment on the US since I have never been there or lived there. I can for sure talk about India for I have lived here all my life.
I am amazed how you could generalise "They are all liars" based on your experience with maybe a dozen maids and drivers!!
Interesting how India/other Indians are responsible for your behavior and made you verbally abuse a hawker during an incident of Road rage. Due to a concern over hygiene, you made the maid use different set of dinnerware. Which with my limited understanding points to discrimination against the maid. Just wondering, would it have been an option to make the maid understand hygiene and change her practices?
In the country which you now reside,(I stress on the fact that I have only heard, since I don't live there) would they tolerate a similar act where you designate a seperate set of dinnerware for your mai?? If you wouldn't do it in the US, why would you do it in India?
I did like the statement, "I hated what I was becoming". I firmly believe what we are or what we become is a direct result of the choices we make in life.
Also, interesting that you mentioned you are optimistic of India's long-term success. I would be keen to find out the experiences which created this impression.

To all those who say that the italicized phrases in the post are the thoughts of society around him, the point of view he saw around him to the dilemmas he faced, and not the authors personal beliefs, I say, reconsider what the author is saying. He's blind to his own faults.
BELIEF is not about what you THINK, but about what you DO.
He DID refuse to help another service class person because of the lies of one of them. SO he imbibed the prejudice. He DID separate his maid's utensils. He DID shout at those beggar children. He did all those things that he attributes to societal pressure. He had choices and made them.
If you've had a privileged upbringing (if he went to the US to study while so young, he surely did), made a great deal of money (as he confesses), are a parent (and so hopefully at least moderately mature), and you make stupid choices all around you, and then crib about not liking what you've become, I'm sorry, I'm not buying... Some serious introspection required by the author, and preferably not on a public forum.

# 57

Hi Navneeth,
Thanks for pointing out '(italics are the voices of the society at large)', because I (#5) indeed missed that. Anyway, it's not the single standard followed. One needs to follow 3-4 extra rules if one is quoting others voices, as per any good writing standards. Anyway, I didn't get them as 'voices of society'. I acknowledge it.

However, the bigger point is - does that change anything. This morning I was reading each of the comments (have reached 57 so far). And it gives me optimism to live in India and have a better society here. Some of the comments, IMHO, was much better than the original post, on same complex individual freedom vs. socioeconomic norms.

Come on Navneeth - what was the sample size this author used to arrive at 'voices of the society at largey'? (alternatively, take a sampling of the 61 or so comments here).You give an estimation, before one makes a comment, as categorical as 'they're all liars' on all private car drivers in India (or was it in Bangalore only?). Point is basic human behavior and psychology isn't much different in Kolkata, Bangalore or in Bay areas. Jeeves of P G Wodehouse realized same, as a butler!

Many of us want to see not what is happening around us in an unbiased way, but based on our individual biases & close friend-family circle interpretation of same. Others have grown up as adults & have been able to see things in an unbiased way, by being in other person's shoes - an objectives of higher education.

It provides multiple perspectives when no single perspective exists. I suggest one refers to couple of articles by Stanley Fish in NYT on Deep in the heart of Texas http://opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/06/21/deep-in-the-heart-of-texas/ & Student Evaluations http://opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/06/28/student-evaluations-part...

I feel sad that author didn't have any teacher like SF who could show him 'how to see three sides of a twosided story'. Failure of his higher edu, where ever it was
Wow.  As someone who looks and at a lot of economic data and reads a lot of (economic) news, this was a fantastic recap.  I hope this is a regular feature.

This writer is a disgrace to both India and America, but not a total loss, for he seems honest!

He should begin to study Bhagvat Geeta, immediately. He is suffering from a disease far more difficult to cure than his condescending admission of "chronic amoebiasis of the soul." His disease is EGO! Geeta will teach him to receive everything as a "gift" and give everything as an "offering" to the creator. His mother ought to send him a copy of "Gita-Rahasya," by Lokmanya Bal Gangadhar Tilak.

India doesn't make you "become" anything. India simply reveals who you already are. If you don't like what you discovered, returning to America will only delay the process of change. But that's the problem we all have to grapple with: what kind of people do we want to be? I am an American woman living in India for the past 31 years - I totally understand the horror of confronting one's worst self. All the best in your journey, Mr Mungee.

Very nicely written story. For the somewhat dull Ranjit Guswami, the author uses italics to show her momentary thoughts that bother her. She is intelligent and mature enough to know that these thoughts are not "truths."
In spite of this eye opening piece, i would be still going back. I think i will have to get my 'chalta hai' back before i do that.

To Malone (#104):

As a fellow Bengali (see #60) of the same circa and a certified card-carrying lefty intellectual (aren't all Bengalis? and no leaning here either), I truly appreciated the Sunil Gangopadhyay quote. It captures the essence of the bifurcation we all feel not only back "there" but here as well at others' helplessness in the face of the system and our own (see Occupy Wall Street). We all deal with it as best we can half way between kicking and kissing, hopefully leaning more toward the kissing, generally in the form of a few paise. And I believe most of the disapprobation of the author derives from the judgment that he chose to be a kicker, however much he wants to rationalize it away.

Noticing your address, I am a bit surprised that your perennial anger at injustices is not kept stoked in the US. I would think SB1070, Jan Brewer and Joe Arpaio would provide enough fuel.

Interesting piece. We need to setup some sort of counseling service for returning NRIs like Sumedh, AUS-CJB etc. They could be dealing with serious coping issues and need help.
The feelings of the authors and some others is largely because of deeply held stereotypes. Come back to India for the positives else you will leave soon because of the negatives.
I have been back for 3 months now and love it, despite the traffic chaos, the filth etc. I came back because I wanted to be a part of the change and not because I wanted to feed off it.
There are few things you never get to choose - the family you are born to and the race that you come from. I am proud to be an Indian and show it by being a part of it, just like the other billion+ Indians.
Albert Pulos, 5 for 5 for #5!  Enough said!

Yeah, I posted before but remember living there in the late '70s in a cheap apartment off East Cenral Avenue. I was in a tempestous relationship with a brilliant and spirited New Mexican woman from a family that had a deed signed by King Philip II of Spain. She died in my arms from leukemia. I will always have a sunny spot in my heart for this dusty, kooky, dopey bum-ridden city. After all, the most incredible experience of my life happened there.  I experienced the heart of Southwestern romance in Albuquerque, and it was a very personal gift.

Daniel #66,

Ah - perhaps we can bounce this around a bit. My own inkling is that the carpet would remain at 20' even at infinite steps. I think there are three ways to support this perspective,

1. The magnification argument. Dr W makes this nicely in #65 and perhaps in #64: as the steps decrease in size you can just increase magnification correspondingly and always see the same picture. The carpet will therefore never change in size.

2. The larger staircase argument: instead of being confined to 10x10 feet you keep the steps the same size and allow the entire staircase to grow to infinite length. Carpet required for each step would remain at 2' even as steps reached infinity.

3. The break-the-steps argument. The initial ten stairs could each be broken into the step and the riser; connecting all risers then all steps would give you a ten foot vertical surface followed by ten feet of horizontal surface, which in total would require the same twenty feet of carpet. Even infinite steps could be reassembled into this configuration, therefore infinite steps continue to take the 20'.

I think the tricky thing in this problem is that if the original set of stairs would placed on a plank and continually subdivided the area between the stairs and plank would approach zero as the steps got smaller and smaller (Dr W's point, I believe). But this doesn't effect the carpet length.

They ran away from the same city ... and the same India ... where this chap hails from ...

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZJZoOGXIXQU

need more be said?
